Message.Title: Intelligence Study Links Low I.Q. to Prejudice, Racism, Conservatism
Message.Msg: From the Huffington Post by Rebecca Serles Are racists dumb? Do conservatives tend to be less intelligent than liberals? A provocative new study from Brock University in Ontario suggests the answer to both questions may be a qualified yes. The study, published in Psychological Science, showed that people who score low on I.Q. tests in childhood are more likely to develop prejudiced beliefs and socially conservative politics in adulthood. I.Q., or intelligence quotient, is a score determined by standardized tests, but whether the tests truly reveal intelligence remains a topic of hot debate among psychologists. Dr. Gordon Hodson, a professor of psychology at the university and the study's lead author, said the finding represented evidence of a vicious cycle: People of low intelligence gravitate toward socially conservative ideologies, which stress resistance to change and, in turn, prejudice, he told LiveScience. Why might less intelligent people be drawn to conservative ideologies? Because such ideologies feature "structure and order" that make it easier to comprehend a complicated world, Dodson said. "Unfortunately, many of these features can also contribute to prejudice," he added. Dr. Brian Nosek, a University of Virginia psychologist, echoed those sentiments. "Reality is complicated and messy," he told The Huffington Post in an email. "Ideologies get rid of the messiness and impose a simpler solution. So, it may not be surprising that people with less cognitive capacity will be attracted to simplifying ideologies." But Nosek said less intelligent types might be attracted to liberal "simplifying ideologies" as well as conservative ones. In any case, the study has taken the Internet by storm, with some outspoken liberals saying that It validates their suspicions about conservatives and conservatives arguing that the research has been misinterpreted.

Message.Title: Bank of America Plans to Repurchase up to $5 Billion in Common Shares and Redeem Approximately $5.5 Billion in Preferred Stock
Message.Msg: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Mar 14, 2013 (BUSINESS WIRE) -- Bank of America today announced that the company's Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to $5.0 billion of common stock and the redemption of approximately $5.5 billion in preferred stock. The Federal Reserve Board has informed the company that it completed its 2013 Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review and that it did not object to the company's capital plan, including proposed capital actions. "We have simplified our company and we have more than adequate capital to support our strategic plans. We are well positioned to return excess capital to our shareholders," said Chief Executive Officer Brian Moynihan. "We believe buying back common shares is the best way to continue to drive value for our shareholders." The timing and exact amount of common share repurchases will be consistent with the company's capital plan and will be subject to various factors, including the company's capital position, liquidity, financial performance and alternative uses of capital, stock trading price, and general market conditions, and may be suspended at any time. The common share repurchases may be effected through open market purchases or privately negotiated transactions, including Rule 10b5-1 plans, over the next four quarters. The company's 2013 capital plan did not include a request to increase the quarterly common stock dividend rate of $0.01 per share. The company's Board of Directors also approved the redemption of all the outstanding shares of two series of the company's preferred stock. The 8.20% Non-Cumulative Preferred Stock, Series H, will be redeemed on May 1, 2013, and the 8.625% Non-Cumulative Preferred Stock, Series 8, will be redeemed on May 28, 2013. The redemption price for each of these preferred stock series will be 100 percent of the liquidation preference per share, as specified in the company's certificate of incorporation. Notice of redemption for each series, including notice to holders

Message.Title: Dividend Forecast Cup Results!!! Winner = gamblin09 / ryanmilliron, CONGRATS!!
Message.Msg: 0 Buyback (annett_sit_stain) No Dividend + BB1.5 Buyback (nobrainer101) 2-3 cent (mystk7) 2-3 cent (croppled1) 3 cent Dividend (amaretto_fianchetto) 3 cent dividend + no buy back (neondros) 4 Cent Dividend (cmegladon) 4 cent Dividend + 1.2B buyback (Nasa_rss) 4 cent + 2.5B Buyback – (gamblin09) 4 cent + 5-7B Buyback – (ryanmilliron) 5 cent Dividend (marshallfolsh) 5 cent Dividend (toothpaste2013) 8 cent + 4.25B Buyback – (soccerdadjon12) Looking at the results, it can be calculated by figures or detailed analyze. There are 2 different results, The results by figure is 5 billon dollar buy back which shows the winner to this Cup is….. ryanmilliron!! Well done!! The second results derive from my calculation which 5 billion buy back equal to 11 cent dividend per quarter. The nearest answer to this should be between gamblin09 and ryanmilliron. gamblin09 = 4 cent dividend + 2.5billion buy back (which is equal to 5.5 cent dividend quarterly) = 9.5 cent dividend ryanmilliron = 4 cent + 6 billion shares buy back (14 cent dividend quarterly) = 18 cent dividend quarterly From the calculation above, gamblin09 should be the nearest winner to this cup!!!! $5 billion buyback = 410million shares/ 10778 million shares = 3.71% shares 3.71% increase = 0.0371*12.11 = 0.45 cent Dividend / quarter = 0.45/4 = 11 cent dividend per quarter.

Message.Msg: 10b buyback is a serious commitment in cash to shareholders, whether it's in the form of a dividend or stock buy back it definitely demonstrates BAC is committed to its shareholders. I personally would rather see a buyback first, because the dividend "costs" the bank more with more outstanding shares. Reduce the outstanding shares first, then increase the dividend. I think that this is about 2x what most people expected for cash to shareholders, and even at the expected levels the stock was touching 12.30 about 2 days ago before it pulled back in fear. I'd expect a pop of about 5%, maybe some profit taking, and a 13.00 price in 2 weeks.

Topic.Title: The 10 billion buy back is accretive by 4 dollars 20 cents per share or more here is why

Message.Msg: I'm not sure how you got 2.38M shares? 5 billion is worth roughly 400 M shares, and 10B was committed. 400M shares is 3.7% of the 10.7 Billion shares outstanding, so the 5 Billion if it had been directed as a dividend would have given us 3.7% return on 12.25, or 45c/year, or 11c/quarter. Given that it was 10b dollars invested instead of 5 billion (even though it wasn't applied to common shares) it would be the equivalent of a 90c dividend. I don't get your calculation.

Topic.Title: .64 to what? big deal and moynihan says buyback is best? BS!

Message.Msg: Why are you so angry? I receive over $2.00 per share in dividends every year on the preferred issues that BofA is going to close out. The least BofA could do is increase the dividend on the common so as to reward investors with revenue since I'm more interested in revenue than capital gain. Moreover, the purchase program takes place over a year. Experience tells me that purchase programs don't increase equity values because investors are never certain when to price the purchase program in until the company notifies that they have completed their program. See you in a year—if the company actually completes the buying program. Worse, purchase programs tend to signal that a company's growth prospects are decreasing and buying back equity is the only way the company can increase value. It sounds like a great idea: paying seventy cents on the dollar—but the market doesn't like it and increasingly discounts the PE even as the company buys its own float. Anyway, had you been observant you would have known these things. Which is fine because I'm ready to embrace another period when low information investors wander around acting like God's gift to the investing world because everything is going up. Happy trails managing your risk.
